quote: The U -Net not only performs well in segmenting multimodal medical images generally, but also in some tough cases of them.
The U-Net and U -Net-like models have been successfully used to segment various biomedical images, such as liver [21], skin lesion [22] and vessels [23].
To apply this inception-like block makes U-Net architecture have the ability to concatenate features learnt from the image at different scales.
Thus, we assumed that those most challenging tasks would be solved if we can provide more different-scale (more effective) features.
In conclusion, Jaccard similarity is a proper measure if segmentation output is binary but for grayscale images, Tanimoto similarity is better.
In our infrared breast dataset, DC-UNet can separate the belly and breast region even they have similar temperature and DC-UNet also provides a more accurate contour.
For those challenging cases, the performance of DC-UNet was better than MultiResUNet and DC-UNet.
DC-UNet can detect vague boundaries and avoid the interference of noise.
U-net: Convolutional networks for biomedical image segmentation.
